awd_titl_txt: Theoretical Studies at the Interface of Atomic Physics and Precision Measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
Cosmological observations indicate that modern physics can explain only a small fraction (about 5%) of the microscopic composition of the Universe. Exacting the nature of the remaining 95%, dark matter and dark energy, is one of the grandest challenges in modern physics. This project aims at finding inroads to solving this outstanding problem through interpretation, design, and characterization of precision measurement experiments carried out in laboratory settings. Such experiments, while being relatively inexpensive, have a tantalizing discovery potential. Any discovery in this area would profoundly help in painting a more complete picture of Nature's inner workings. Historically, such advances eventually lead to technological advances. The project will train a young theoretical/computational physicist, contributing to the high-technology workforce development. The project will be carried out in Nevada, a state historically underrepresented in the scientific enterprise, thus contributing to diversity.  

A signal of new physics may come as a small perturbation on top of a conventional Standard Model physics background; thereby an interpretation of experimental measurements requires input from theoretical calculations characterizing such backgrounds. A major part of this project deals with  high-precision calculations of atomic properties required for improved  interpretation of the violation of mirror symmetry in atoms. Together with previous experimental results, the calculations will either reveal new physics or place powerful constraints on the dark sector.  Another part of the project will estimate fundamental physics limitations on the accuracies attainable with atomic timekeeping and also improve the interpretation of searches for ultralight dark matter with precision instruments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: 

This project explored applications at the intersection of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical (AMO) physics with fundamental physics, quantum sensing and astronomy. We developed a novel concept in multi-messenger astronomy, utilizing precision quantum sensor networks to detect astrophysical signals from black hole mergers. One of the grand challenges in modern physics is the development of theory of quantum gravity.  We argued that some of the emitted energy from the mergers may be carried out in the previously undetected modality, potentially enabling detection of quantum gravity signatures, Moreover, we elucidated the stochastic nature of ultralight dark matter and established improved constraints on its interaction strength from atomic clock data. Despite substantial evidence for dark matter existence, exacting its nature remains a challenge for modern physics and cosmology. Finally, our rigorous computational approaches provided refined atomic data and methodology, laying the foundation for improved tests of the standard model of elementary particles through atomic parity violation. While our progress was motivated by fundamental physics applications, the refined atomic structure codes have been used in quantum technology developments. 

Broader Impacts:

This project extended beyond the confines of AMO physics, impacting other scientific disciplines such as astronomy and particle physics. The project supported a postdoctoral fellow, undergraduate, and graduate students, nurturing the upcoming generation of physicists. We disseminated our findings through publications in peer-reviewed journals, media interviews, and presentations at conferences and workshops. This ensured that our scientific contributions were accessible to both the academic community and the broader public. The research has been carried out in Nevada, one of the EPSCoR states traditionally underrepresented in scientific enterprise.
